title: Bluecrest Equips Students On Ethical Hacking
text:
12 August 2015 09:37 CET Bluecrest Equips Students On Ethical Hacking By Daily Guide 
Bluecrest College has started a series of free interactive workshops on latest technologies to help minimize the gap between academic qualification and professional performance on the job market. 
With its solid background of imparting ICT education to more than 50,000 students through NIIT, BlueCrest is sure of bridging this gap to produce graduates who are industry ready. 
In line with this, the College recently organized a free 'Ethical Hacking and Counter measures' training for some 200 SHS students from various schools. 
The training programme was organized by college's Centre for Career & Professional Development (CCPD) at its Accra campus. 
CCPD has been established with the aim of bridging academiaâ€industry gap. 
The centre provides training and consultancy for the industry in the field of Information Technology with focus on high-end and latest technologies such as Ethical Hacking, Cloud Computing, 3D Game Development etc. 
Vibin Chandar, a network security expert, said as internet penetration increases, there is bound to be a corresponding increase in challenges to secure confidential data from hacks. 
'The main theme of this training was to train students for pre-emptive measures against malicious attacks by exposing the vulnerabilities of their own systems using the same techniques that are used by hackers. This skill of an Ethical Hacker has proven invaluable to protect organizations around the world. 
'There is a sense of alarm and dismay when some state websites are hacked and are down for a while. If the nation does not develop and implement a cyber-security strategy to address cyber warfare, sabotage and espionage there could be more of such attacks on public and private establishments. The need for information security for security compliance in Ghana is mandatory for all companies with an IT backbone.' 
The information security industry is growing at a current worldwide growth rate of 21% percent, adding that there are an estimated 2.28 million information security professionals worldwide who are expected to increase to nearly 4.2 million this year.
